Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 17: The Imperial Guard
King Shuddhodana (Zas gtsang) got his brothers and all the nobles of the kingdom together to discuss how to prevent Siddhartha from giving up on the throne.
Manual - English: The city of Kapilavastu (ser skya) with seven concentric rings of moats and walls is heavily guarded. Five hundred men seal the iron gate. Another five hundred men puts up a giant ladder and collects it. Soldiers guard within every wall. The Buddha's palace is guarded by the king's four brothers. There is the Buddha in the palace. In a room in the palace, many women play music instruments and make various offerings. Aniruddha (ma 'gags pa) is on watch outside the palace.

Sun of Faith - English: “The city is already fortified by seven walls and seven moats.
Let's lock the massive city portals with iron locks
and hang bells cast in a particularly resonant metal on top of them:
if the prince tries to open the gates, the clanging of the bells will be heard for miles around.
And what of the gigantic exterior ladder? We must have it removed every evening by a crew of five hundred stalwarts,
and re-placed in the morning by another crew.
As for the Bodhisattva, let's keep him confined to the upper stories of the palace, and surrounded by a circle of the most beautiful women.
Dancers, singers and musicians shall weave their charms and hold him spellbound.
Four ministers will command the four divisions of the armed forces, and will closely watch the external fortifications.
Every night King Shuddhodana and his troops will stand guard in front of the eastern gates;
the west will be protected by Shuklodana (Zas dkar);
the south by Dronodana (Bre bo zas);
and the north by Amrtodana (Bdud rtsi zas).
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu refers to this uncle as "tshad med zas" rather than "bdud rtsi zas"

Sun of Faith - English: Mahanaman (Shakya ming chen) will see to it that this configuration is adhered to.”
On the first of the seven nights, in the course of the first watch, the Shakya guard Mahanaman appeared at the eastern gate. He demanded, “Who is on duty here?”
“I am,” Shuddhodana replied.
The guard urged: “O king, for your own good, stay awake!
That common thing, sleep, makes us assume the form of corpses.  The sleeping fall prey to demons.
Those who resist sleep are cleverer. Banish it therefore and stand guard!"
He then visited the king's brothers' troops who were stationed at the southern, western and northern gates, as well as the ministers' units and exhorted them in the same manner.
He made his rounds every two hours and at first light, proclaiming: “Out of seven nights of guard duty, one down. Six more to go.”
Six long days elapsed thus.
On the eve of the seventh, the lord of the gods, Indra (Brgya byin), came to spur on the Bodhisattva,

who had been considering within himself: “In future times, detractors might claim that I was able to leave the company of sixty thousand extraordinary women, and prefer the life of a renunciate to them because I am not really a human being.
That, in turn, could lead to all sorts of rumors belying the real state of affairs.”
Consequently, he made his principal wife, Yasodhara (Grags ’dzin ma), pregnant.
The queen, feeling that a being had just taken refuge in her body, promised herself that she would tell her husband the wonderful news the very next day.
